original_data.question: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department because of fever and diarrhea. He was in his normal state of health until 2 weeks ago when he went abroad on a vacation. During his trip he went kayaking, visited spas, interacted with local animals, and ate local foods. Since returning he has had 3-day history of fever, cough, headache, and diarrhea. He drinks socially and has a 15-pack-year history of smoking. On presentation his temperature is 102.3°F (39.1°C), blood pressure is 105/62 mmHg, pulse is 91/min, respirations are 18/min, and O2 saturation is 91% on room air. Chest exam reveals fine crackles on auscultation. Chest radiograph reveals patchy infiltrates in both lungs and labs reveal mild hyponatremia and mild elevation of AST/ALT levels. The organism that is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms is associated with which of the following characteristics?

options.C: Is more common in parrot owners

model_response:
The patient's symptoms are most consistent with an atypical pneumonia. The most common organism causing atypical pneumonia is Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Mycoplasma pneumoniae can be difficult to culture, but can be detected by cold agglutinins, which are autoantibodies that agglutinate sheep erythrocytes. Mycoplasma pneumoniae can form an endospore, which allows it to survive in the environment for prolonged periods of time. It is a small gram-negative bacterium that is part of the normal flora of the respiratory tract. It is transmitted person-to-person via respiratory secretions. It does not have a cell wall, which makes it resistant to the action of penicillin and other beta-lactam antibiotics. It is more common in people who have close contact with birds, such as pigeons and parrots. Mycoplasma pneumoniae is also associated with arthritis, pericarditis, and aseptic meningitis. Legionella pneumophila is a gram-negative bacillus that is found in aerosols generated by cooling towers and air conditioning systems. It is associated with a severe form of pneumonia called Legionnaire disease. Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative bacillus that is a common cause of pneumonia in patients with COPD. It is a major pathogen in patients with COPD and is a common cause of exacerbations. It is a major pathogen in patients with COPD who have been treated with a fluoroquinolone antibiotic. It is not associated with an atypical pneumonia.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.

An increased liquidity or decreased consistency of FECES, such as running stool. Fecal consistency is related to the ratio of water-holding capacity of insoluble solids to total water, rather than the amount of water present. Diarrhea is not hyperdefecation or increased fecal weight.
Condition of existence, or state of awareness, in which psychological needs are satisfied
The state of the organism when it functions optimally without evidence of disease.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
Leisure time away from work devoted to rest or pleasure.

Unicellular or multicellular, heterotrophic organisms, that have sensation and the power of voluntary movement. Under the older five kingdom paradigm, Animalia was one of the kingdoms. Under the modern three domain model, Animalia represents one of the many groups in the domain EUKARYOTA.
Record and study of past events.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.

A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation. It is a protective response that serves to clear the trachea, bronchi, and/or lungs of irritants and secretions, or to prevent aspiration of foreign materials into the lungs.
The symptom of PAIN in the cranial region. It may be an isolated benign occurrence or manifestation of a wide variety of HEADACHE DISORDERS.

An increased liquidity or decreased consistency of FECES, such as running stool. Fecal consistency is related to the ratio of water-holding capacity of insoluble solids to total water, rather than the amount of water present. Diarrhea is not hyperdefecation or increased fecal weight.
A single serving of a beverage; any liquid suitable for drinking.
Relating to human society and its members.
Willful or deliberate act of inhaling and exhaling SMOKE from burning substances or agents held by hand.
To show or display; the act of presenting something to sight or view: how something looks.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A non-SI unit of pressure equal to 133,332 Pa or 1.316E10-3 standard atmosphere. Use of this unit is generally deprecated by ISO and IUPAC.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).

The determination of oxygen-hemoglobin saturation of blood either by withdrawing a sample and passing it through a classical photoelectric oximeter or by electrodes attached to some translucent part of the body like finger, earlobe, or skin fold. It includes non-invasive oxygen monitoring by pulse oximetry.
Unmodified air as existing in the immediate surroundings.
The upper part of the trunk between the NECK and the ABDOMEN. It contains the chief organs of the circulatory and respiratory systems. (From Stedman, 25th ed)
Abnormal breath sounds (crackles) heard on auscultation, indicating inflammation, fluid, or infection of the lung.
Act of listening for sounds within the body.
Either of the pair of organs occupying the cavity of the thorax that effect the aeration of the blood.
The outcome of a laboratory test.
Deficiency of sodium in the blood; salt depletion. (Dorland, 27th ed)
The condition of being elevated.
A living entity.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
Joined in some kind of relationship.
The distinguishing qualities or prominent aspect of a person, object, action, process, or substance.
